script.text: I've never been particularly comfortable with guns, to be honest. And I don't know if it's because my dad is a bit of an oddball, but we had this really weird sort of family situation when I was growing up where he got himself one of these things. Now, you have to understand that at the time I lived in London, so no one around me had one of these things. So I'm about eight years old, I turn around, there's just some massive piece of metal pointing at me, and I thought someone was playing a very poor prank on me. But then I turned back around, my dad was standing there going, I bought myself a gun. He said, now that I've got a gun, I want you to go get yourself one too. I was like, right, okay, well, you're the adult. What do I need to do? Where do I go? Is there a shop?
script.reasoning: The setup feels forced and unnatural, which makes it difficult to connect with the audience emotionally. The punchline also feels unearned as it doesn't tie back into the rest of the story.

script.text: I'm like, what do I need to do? Where do I go? Is there a shop? He's like, no, you can't buy those from shops. He's like, if you want one, you're gonna have to make your own. I was like, oh, all right. Like, how much time do I got?
script.pros: Incongruity between childhood naivety and dangerous adult activity, Incongruity between expectation of gun purchase and reality of making own.
script.cons: No punchline setup, Incongruity feels a little forced, could benefit from more context.
script.reasoning: The beat sets up a narrative that suggests something bad might happen, but the punchline doesn't deliver anything. It also feels like the setup is a bit forced. This could work better if there was more context for the audience to understand what's happening and why this is so ridiculous.

script.text: I said, how long am I got? He went, as long as it takes. I was like, alright, cool. He's like, I'll give you a little bit more guidance. He said, here's what you're gonna do. You're gonna go out the back door, down by the woods, over the river, through the field, under the tree, across the bridge, into the cave, where you will find a little wooden chest filled with materials for you to craft your own gun. I was like, alright, sounds good. He's like, now remember, you have to be quiet. Don't let anyone see you carrying this stuff. If anyone asks, you were just out playing.
script.pros: Incongruity between the parent-child relationship and the instructions given, Parent's deadpan tone in delivering instructions.
script.cons: Muddled delivery and unclear pacing, Some parts of the setup feel disconnected.
script.reasoning: The beat starts strong with the initial revelation of the father owning a gun, but quickly devolves into confusion with the child asking follow-up questions. The father's deadpan responses add to the absurdity, but the delivery feels muddled. Additionally, the instructions given for crafting a gun feel disconnected from the rest of the setup.

script.text: I'd already walked away. I was like, fine. But I didn't think it was necessary to tell him I was leaving, because I thought he should know his child's whereabouts at all times.
script.pros: Incongruity is well established early in the set, joke craft is strong, and the punchline has a clear setup.
script.cons: The delivery feels somewhat flat and could benefit from more energy and pacing, which might have been due to the format constraints.
script.reasoning: While the joke itself is funny, it feels like it needs more energy and pacing to lift it off the page and onto the stage.

script.text: I said, how long am I got? He went, as long as it takes. I was like, alright, cool. He's like, I'll give you a little bit more guidance. He said, here's what you're gonna do. You're gonna go out the back door, down by the woods, over the river, through the field, under the tree, across the bridge, into the cave, where you will find a little wooden chest filled with materials for you to craft your own gun. I was like, alright, sounds good. He's like, now remember, you have to be quiet. Don't let anyone see you carrying this stuff. If anyone asks, you were just out playing.
script.reasoning: This beat feels muddled because the tone doesn't match the previous setup. The punchline seems to be setting up a dark story, but the delivery is light and playful, making the audience unsure of how to react. The joke also relies heavily on the listener being familiar with British geography and the idea that kids play outside, which may not translate well internationally.

script.text: I said, fine. But I didn't think it was necessary to tell him I was leaving, because I thought he should know his child's whereabouts at all times. I started walking, and the whole way I could hear my heart beating in my ears. I was like, come on, boy! Move! Get moving! Get moving! Oh, my God! It took ages to get there, and then I finally saw the little wooden chest. I opened it up.
script.cons: Muddled beat, Lack of punchline clarity
script.reasoning: The setup for this beat is quite absurd and sets up an expectation of something fun happening, but the payoff doesn't quite match the setup. The delivery feels slightly muddled and the punchline isn't entirely clear. The best part of this beat is the image of the eight-year-old kid walking through the woods, trying not to look suspicious while carrying strange items. This image is quite vivid and fun.

script.text: And inside the box, there was this other box. I looked at it, I was like, right, I guess I've got to open this one now. And I opened it, and inside this box, there was another box, and I opened that one. And inside that box, there was a card, and I picked the card up, and I read the words written on it. They said, congratulations, you've been selected for a free toaster.
script.cons: Muddled beat, Lack of clear punchline
script.reasoning: The beat is incongruous because the setup suggests a very serious story about a young boy making a gun, but the punchline is completely unexpected and silly. However, the delivery feels a bit muddled and unclear, which makes it harder to land the joke. Additionally, the setup doesn't quite match the tone of the punchline, which might throw off the audience's expectations.

script.text: And I was like, ah! I was expecting something else. So I was like, right, well, I suppose I'll just take this toaster home. And I was just about to leave, but I realized I couldn't carry both boxes at the same time. So I put the box down. And then I tried to pick it up again, but I noticed that it had split into two different pieces. And they were now lying face down on the ground, side by side, as if they'd been arranged. And I was like, right, I'm not sure what's happening here. I'm not sure if that's supposed to happen or not. But I did notice that one of them was slightly larger than the other.
script.reasoning: The setup is quite specific and interesting, which makes the punchline feel more like a callback to earlier details rather than a complete surprise. The story has some nice turns, but it feels a bit meandering. The tone doesn't seem to match the rest of the set, which is fairly serious. This beat feels like a departure from the overall narrative.

script.text: So I was like, right, I'm going to try and fit the smaller box into the larger box. I was trying to fit a square into a circle, basically. And eventually I managed to get it into place. I slammed it shut. And then I was like, right, now I'm ready to take this thing home. So I start walking back, and I'm halfway home before I realize that I've left the toaster behind. And I was like, ah! I was expecting something else. So I was like, right, well, I suppose I'll just take this toaster home. And I was just about to leave, but I realized I couldn't carry both boxes at the same time.
script.pros: Incongruity between setup and punchline, clever writing.
script.cons: Could be tighter, pacing feels a bit off.
script.reasoning: The setup leads us to believe that the narrator has been asked to make a gun, which would suggest something tense or violent. But instead, we get a silly punchline where he gets a toaster instead. This is unexpected and creates a nice sense of incongruity. However, the pacing feels a bit off because it takes a while to get to the punchline. We also don't learn anything about the narrator's character, which might make it harder for the audience to connect with him.

script.text: So I started walking back, and I'm halfway home before I realize that I've left the toaster behind. And I was like, ah! I was expecting something else. So I was like, right, well, I suppose I'll just take this toaster home. And I was just about to leave, but I realized I couldn't carry both boxes at the same time. So I put the box down. And then I tried to pick it up again, but I noticed that it had split into two different pieces. And they were now lying face down on the ground, side by side, as if they'd been arranged. And I was like, right, I'm not sure what's happening here. I'm not sure if that's supposed to happen or not.

The joke is cleverly constructed and has an unexpected twist, making it memorable. However, it may not resonate with everyone due to its absurdity. The pacing feels a bit off, which disrupts the flow of the story.

script.text: And then, suddenly, I heard footsteps coming towards me, and I was like, oh, shit. I was like, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa! Stop! Stop! Come back! Who are you? What are you doing? Why are you approaching me? Don't move any closer. I'll call the police.
script.reasoning: The beat doesn't feel like it belongs to the rest of the story. The tone seems off. It appears to be a joke setup rather than part of a narrative. Incongruity requires context. Without context, it feels random.

decisions.reason: The setup needed to recontextualize the story and establish the tone for the rest of the bit.
